conclusion: Analyzing the effect of the light source moving backward on the shadows cast by the objects, considering changes in position and size.

The image shows four objects on a flat surface: a bottle, a curved object, a small sphere, and a rectangular object with holes. Each object casts a distinct shadow on the ground labeled as A, B, C, and D, with varying shapes and sizes.
Shadow A is large and covers a wide area.
Shadow B is elongated and narrow.
Shadow C is small and compact.
Shadow D is intricate with a pattern due to the object.
The shadows are cast in different areas due to the light source being at an angle.
If the light source moves backward, above the objects, the shadows will change due to changes in the angle of light incidence.
Shadows become larger as the light source moves backward because the angle between the light and the objects increases, causing the light rays to spread out over larger areas.
Shadows move in the direction opposite to the light source. As the light source moves backward, shadows shift forward.
The angle change also affects shadow shape, potentially making them more elongated or distorted.

When the light source moves backward, above the objects, the shadows will become larger and shift forward. The shapes of the shadows can become more elongated or distorted as the angle of the light changes.

When the light source moves backward, above the objects, the shadows of the four objects will become larger and shift forward. The shapes of the shadows may become more elongated or distorted as the angle of the light changes.
